dialogue.speaker: Grandmother

dialogue.speaker: The Wolf
dialogue.dialogue: Oh, it's just a touch of the chill from the woods, Grandmother—nothing to worry about; I promise your favorite stew is piping hot.

dialogue.speaker: Grandmother
dialogue.dialogue: Stew, you say? Let me see your hands—hold them up to the candlelight, dear, so I can be sure it's you.
dialogue.action: Grandmother sits up in bed, clutching her blanket a little tighter, peering anxiously toward the door.

dialogue.speaker: The Wolf
dialogue.dialogue: Of course, Grandmother—see, here they are, though the shadows from the candle make them look larger than usual, don't they?
dialogue.action: The Wolf slowly extends his clawed paws into the flickering candlelight, trying to keep them partially hidden beneath the folds of a borrowed shawl.

dialogue.speaker: Grandmother
dialogue.dialogue: My, but your hands do look so rough and strong tonight—almost like a hunter's, not my sweet grandchild's.
dialogue.action: Grandmother clutches the blanket tighter around her shoulders, her eyes narrowing as she leans closer to inspect the Wolf's hands.

dialogue.speaker: The Wolf
dialogue.dialogue: Oh, Grandmother, it's only from carrying your heavy supper basket through the brambles—surely you wouldn't turn me away when I'm so hungry for your company?
dialogue.action: The Wolf steps closer to the bed, keeping his hands just at the edge of the candlelight, his eyes glinting in the shadow.

dialogue.speaker: Grandmother
dialogue.dialogue: Well, step closer then, but mind you keep to the light—my eyes are not what they were, and I must be certain before I share my table.
dialogue.action: Grandmother tightens her grip on her shawl, peering intently at the figure silhouetted in the doorway.

dialogue.speaker: The Wolf
dialogue.dialogue: Of course, Grandmother—let me set the basket down where you can see every morsel, and perhaps you'll see it's truly me after all.
dialogue.action: The Wolf edges closer, placing the basket in the pool of candlelight, his shadow looming large on the wall behind him.

dialogue.speaker: Grandmother
dialogue.dialogue: Very well, but let me look into your eyes, for they always told me the truth when your voice could not.
dialogue.action: Grandmother leans forward, squinting into the dim candlelight, her hands trembling just above the table.

dialogue.speaker: The Wolf
dialogue.dialogue: Why, Grandmother, my eyes may seem brighter tonight—it's only the reflection of your warm fire, drawing me ever closer.
dialogue.action: The Wolf leans forward, his gaze fixed intently on Grandmother, casting an elongated shadow across the room.

dialogue.speaker: Grandmother
dialogue.dialogue: Your eyes glisten so strangely, child—almost as if they hunger for something more than supper.
dialogue.action: Grandmother leans forward, narrowing her gaze, her trembling hand clutching the edge of the candlelit table.

dialogue.speaker: The Wolf
dialogue.dialogue: Why, Grandmother, perhaps it's just the excitement of seeing you again after so long—my appetite is keen, but only for your company.
dialogue.action: The Wolf leans forward, letting the firelight catch his eyes as he places the basket with deliberate care upon the table.

dialogue.speaker: Grandmother
dialogue.dialogue: Then let the firelight fall full upon your face, dear, for shadows can hide much that the heart ought to see.
dialogue.action: Grandmother sits forward in her chair, clutching her shawl tightly and watching the Wolf with wary eyes.

dialogue.speaker: The Wolf
dialogue.dialogue: Certainly, Grandmother—come closer and see for yourself, every feature plain as day in the glow.
dialogue.action: The Wolf leans in, letting the flickering firelight illuminate his face, a sly smile curling at the edge of his mouth.

dialogue.speaker: Grandmother
dialogue.dialogue: I shall, but my heart trembles, for your face in the firelight is not the one I remember—who are you truly?

dialogue.speaker: The Wolf
dialogue.dialogue: Why, Grandmother, isn't it enough that I've brought you supper and warmth—must you question who stands before you?
dialogue.action: The Wolf steps forward, casting a looming shadow across the hearth as Grandmother grips the edge of her chair, her knuckles white.

dialogue.speaker: Grandmother
dialogue.dialogue: If you are truly my grandchild, then tell me—what song did I sing you each night before supper, for only you and I would know its tune?
dialogue.action: Grandmother clutches her shawl tighter, her eyes narrowing as she leans forward, searching the Wolf's face for any sign of familiarity.

dialogue.speaker: The Wolf
dialogue.dialogue: Ah, Grandmother, the tune escapes me tonight—perhaps if you hum the first few notes, my memory will return.
dialogue.action: The Wolf leans forward, eyes glinting in the firelight, hands tense on the basket as Grandmother draws back, her suspicion deepening.

dialogue.speaker: Grandmother
